National & Local Joint Engineering Laboratory for New Petro-chemical Materials and Fine Utilization of Resources Key Laboratory of the Assembly and Application of Organic Functional Molecules of Hunan Province Hunan Normal University Changsha 410081 PR China A series of highly active and ortho-position selective catalysts based on (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts were proposed for the C-methylation of phenol with methanol. The (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts were synthesized by coprecipitation method of Fe and V elements and microwave drying. The chemical composition, material structure, acid-base properties, and structure-activity relationship of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts were systematically analyzed by the techniques of XRD, XPS, TEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, Raman, UV-Vis, ESR, NH3/CO2-TPD and Pyridine-IR. The (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts have the double advantages of high activity and high stability for the methylation of phenol due to the high BET surface area, large total pore volume, dispersive active sites and enhanced acid-base property. o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol were the main products, and nearly 100% selectivity to the ortho-position of phenol and 90% selectivity to o-cresol were obtained. Furthermore, the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts possess long lifetime over 2500 h and high activity at a weight hourly space velocity of 1.6 h−1 compared with the microwave-dried α-Fe2O3 catalyst. The doping of vanadium improves the activity and stability of α-Fe2O3 catalyst, which attributes to the modification of catalyst structure, especially the improvement of acid-base centers and oxygen vacancy. Recently the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts have been stably and efficiently applied in industry for the methylation of phenol. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords o-cresol C-methylation Ortho-position selectivity V-doped α-Fe2O3 1 Introduction Due to the importance of o-cresol and 2,6-xylenols as chemicals for various industrial applications, the development of catalytic system for the C-methylation of phenol with methanol has been received significant attention [1,2]. The alkylation of phenol with methanol can be divided into two types: liquid-phase alkylation [3–7] or gas-phase alkylation [8–11]. Alkylation reaction generally yields O-alkylation or C-alkylation products, founded on the difference of catalysts and reaction conditions. The liquid-phase methylation of phenol with methanol usually yields a series of anisole, m-cresol, p-cresol over zeolite catalysts at 300 °C [3,4]. Meanwhile the gas-phase methylation of phenol with methanol usually yields a series of o-cresol, 2,6-xylenol, m-cresol, p-cresol and anisole over the solid metal oxides at 250∼400 °C. The gas-phase phenol methylation with methanol yields o-cresol is widely used in the chemical industry, more importantly, the catalyst plays a key role in the reaction. In the past few years, a large number of catalysts have been reported for phenol gas-phase alkylation with methanol in literature and patents. For instance, HZSM-5, Hβ, MCM-41, MCM-48, and HMCM-22 molecular sieves [1,2,12–18] have better catalytic performance with the phenol conversion nearly 40% at low reaction temperature below 350 °C, but they suffer from the generation of various methylated phenols such as anisole, m-cresol and p-cresol, and which rarely select to the ortho-position of C-methylated phenols o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol, meanwhile the single component Al2O3 also shows general catalytic performance at low reaction temperature of 230 °C, but the reaction also yields much more anisole [1]. Other single metallic oxide such as TiO2, CeO2, MgO, and ZrO2 are found to exhibit higher selectivity to the ortho-position of C-methylated phenols over 97%, however the catalytic activity also rather low with the phenol conversion below 40% at higher reaction temperature over 400 °C [19–27]. Meanwhile, MnO2 oxides are reported to have phenol conversion nearly 95% at high temperature of 450 °C, but the reaction shows less selectivity to ortho-position C-methylated phenol, and usually yields a lot 2,4,6-trimethylphenols [28]. Recently, Fe2O3 as an actively catalytic component for the gas-phase C-methylation of phenol with methanol are recorded [29–38]. In the heterogeneous catalytic system, Fe2O3 based catalysts as active centers exhibit better catalytic performance with high ortho-selectivity over 99% and better catalytic activity over 40% phenol conversion at the relatively low reaction temperature (320 ∼ 350 °C). But the previous Fe2O3 based catalytic system shows worse activity at high WHSV (weight hourly space velocity), short catalyst lifetime, more carton deposition and agglomeration, due to the small BET surface area, total pore volume, particle size, surface actives and acid-base property. In order to improve the performance of phenol methylation with methanol, the key factor is to enhance or modify the surfaced active centers of Fe2O3 catalysts. The modified catalysts such as CoFe2O4, Zn1-x CoFe2O4, Ni1-x CoFe2O4, and Cu0.5Co0.5Fe2O4 have been reported as MFe2O4 spinels are used in the catalytic reaction [29–38], which maintain superior performance at relatively low reaction temperature (320 ∼350 °C) and high ortho-selectivity (99%), but MFe2O4 spinel catalysts cannot continuously operate at higher WHSV (over 1.0 h−1) and longer lifetimes (over 1000 h) for the industrial requires. A mechanism of acid-base synergistic catalysis for the phenol C-methylation with methanol is widely reported over Fe2O3 based catalysts [38], therefore we previously had prepared the new typed Fe2O3 based catalysts with high surface areas (110 m2/g), small particle size, more Fe3+ active sites via a novel microwave drying process [39], we also developed a series of mesoporous Fe2O3(x)/SBA-15 materials with surface areas as high as 700 m2/g [40]. Previous Fe2O3 based catalysts had high surface areas with enhanced acid-base property and showed superior catalytic performance in the phenol C-methylation with methanol, but which cannot accord with the standard of industry requires at high WHSV (over 1.0 h−1) while maintaining good performance. In order to further improve the catalytic performance of Fe2O3 based catalysts reacted at higher WHSV (over 1.0 h−1), the strategic approach is to enhance or modify the acid-base actives and Fe2O3 structure. Such catalytic actives and new Fe2O3 structure can be modified by VO x to obtain a better catalytic performance in reaction, which had been reported in many catalytic systems [41,42]. To achieve optimal catalytic performance, a suitable amount of VO x loading into the catalyst help create new actives and material composition, thereby improve the catalytic activity and stability [38]. Our work is aimed at a modification research of V-doped α-Fe2O3 catalyst. The previous microwave drying method [39] has been applied in our work through coprecipitation for the preparation of a new type (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalyst for the phenol C-methylation with methanol. The preparation, characterization, catalytic performance, structure-activity relationship of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts for the phenol C-methylation with methanol are deeply studied in this paper. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Iron (III) nitrate nonahydrate, Fe(NO3)3 •9(H2O) (AR); ammonium vanadate (V), NH4VO3 (AR); phenol, C6H5OH (AR); methanol, CH3OH (AR) from the Aladdin Reagents. 2.2 Catalyst preparation The series of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts with microwave drying are obtained via a coprecipitation method [39]. Typically, 100 g Fe(NO3)3•9H2O was mixed with 0.146 g NH4VO3 by continuous stirring at 70 °C. The resultant V-doped (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 was the Fe2O3 catalyst with V/Fe content ratio of about 0.5/100 (mol.). The mixed solution showed pH value of 9.0 and was subsequently filtered after continuous stirring for 8 h. The filtered precipitate was dried by microwave radiation at maximum output power of 900 W for 20 min and was further calcined at 450 °C for 5 h. The (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts with different V/Fe content ratio (mol.) were separately denoted as (α-Fe2O3)0.999(V2O5)0.001, (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005, (α-Fe2O3)0.99(V2O5)0.01, (α-Fe2O3)0.98(V2O5)0.02, (α-Fe2O3)0.97(V2O5)0.03 and α-Fe2O3. The ultimate catalysts for the phenol methylation were obtained after tableting and sieving at 40–60 mesh. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The phase and crystal structure of the catalysts was detected by X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns using Dmax1200 X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku, Japan). The morphology and structure were obtained by JEM-3100F transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEOL, Japan). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) special surface areas were obtained by nitrogen adsorption apparatus, and recorded by ASAP2400 physisorption instrument (Micromeritics, USA). The component and valence states of the obtained samples were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) performing with K-Alpha 1063 spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). Acid-base content of the catalysts was performed by the NH3/CO2-TPD (Temperature-programmed desorption), and recorded by Chembet-3000 chemical adsorption instrument (Quantachrome, USA). Lewis-Bronsted acid of the catalysts was analyzed by thermo-Nicolet AVATAR 370 Pyridine-IR Spectrometer (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA). Raman spectrums were measured by RamLab-010 confocal microscope Raman spectrometer (Jobin Yvon, France). UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) was performed on UV-2550 UV-vis spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan). Electron spin resonance (ESR) spectra was recorded on a Bruker EMX-10/12 spectrometer at the X-band at ambient temperature (Bruker, USA). 2.4 Catalyst evaluation The reaction was conducted at atmospheric pressure using a vapor-phase setup with a vertical, down-flow, fixed-bed reactor (stainless steel tubular reactor, the inner diameter 16 mm, length 650 mm, catalyst loading capacity 80 mL) in Scheme 1 . 75 g catalyst with particle sizes around 40–60 meshes was charged each time in the center of the reactor such that the catalyst was sandwiched between the layers of inert silica sand. A premixed solution with phenol/methanol/water was pumped into the reactor by LB-05 type constant flux pump from Beijing satellite manufacturing plant. The upper portion of the reactor served as a vaporizer pre-heater, and the mixture was heated up to vapor-phase. Reaction products were sampled and analyzed at regular intervals. An HP 5890 gas chromatograph was adopted, and the length of the BD-1 chromatographic column was 50 m. Analysis conditions: column temperature was kept at 80 °C for 3 min, and then heated up to 220 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C/min for 20 min. Afterwards, quantitative analysis was carried out using the area normalization method. The calculation method of phenol conversion, o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol selectivity was listed as follows, where ortho-selectivity was the total selectivity of o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol. C phenol % = o − cresol × 94 108 + p − cresol × 94 108 + 2 , 6 − xylenol × 94 122 + 2 , 4 − xylenol × 94 122 The initial amount of phenol × 100 % S o − cresol % = o − cresol × 94 108 o − cresol × 94 108 + p − cresol × 94 108 + 2 , 6 − xylenol × 94 122 + 2 , 4 − xylenol × 94 122 × 100 % S 2 , 6 − xylenol % = 2 , 6 − xylenol × 94 122 o − cresol × 94 108 + p − cresol × 94 108 + 2 , 6 − xylenol × 94 122 + 2 , 4 − xylenol × 94 122 × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Initial performance of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x With the increase of V content, the BET specific surface areas measured by Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method (SBET) and total pore volume (Vtotal) of the catalysts both gradually increase at Table 1 . The reason is that the addition of V2O5 leads to form new Fe-V-O phase, thereby the BET specific surface area and pore increase in the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts than α-Fe2O3, and (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x maintain better catalytic performance. Particularly, the optimum catalytic performance is found in the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005, with the phenol conversion of 95.5%, o-cresol selectivity of 62.3%, 2,6-xylenol selectivity of 37.2%, ortho-selectivity up to 99.5%, and catalytic activity nearly two times improvement than that of α-Fe2O3. As phenol conversion increases after doping, the o-cresol selectivity is reduced and the 2,6-xylenol selectivity is improved, which are attributed to the cascade process of o-cresol methylation [10,38,49]. With the increase of V2O5-doped content, the catalytic activity of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x initially increases (x, 0∼0.005) and then declines (x, 0.005∼0.03) with a high ortho-selectivity above 99.3%, but yields slight amounts of by-products (e.g. m-cresol or p-cresol) during this process. Therefore, the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts are feasible for phenol methylation with methanol in the industrial system because of their excellent initial catalytic performance and high purity. 3.2 Influence factors of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x As showed in Fig. 1 (a), with the rise of calcination temperature, the SBET of the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 first increase (350∼450 °C) and then drop (450∼750 °C). Meanwhile, the Vtotal gradually increases first (350∼450 °C) and then decreases (450∼750 °C). A maximum value was obtained at 450 °C for both SBET and Vtotal. The reason is that when the calcination temperature is too low, the pores and structure of catalysts cannot be formed, whereas when the reaction temperature is too high, it will lead to the collapse of pores and structure, and thereby the aggregation of catalyst actives [45]. For the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst, with the rise of calcination temperature, the catalytic activity is firstly enhanced and then weakened. Owing to the increase of catalytic performance, the o-cresol selectivity is reduced, and the 2,6-xylenol selectivity is enhanced. The optimal result is that phenol conversion of 95.5%, o-cresol selectivity of 62.3%, 2,6-xylenol selectivity of 37.2% and ortho-selectivity of 99.5%. At this moment, the SBET (120 m2/g) and Vtotal (0.41 cm3/g) are both the highest, suggesting that the superior physical structures have better catalytic performance. As showed in Fig. 1 (b), at the WHSV of 0.4∼1.6 h−1, the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalytic performance outperformed that of the α-Fe2O3 catalyst. It is seen that the catalytic performance of α-Fe2O3 is the phenol conversion of 67.0%, o-cresol selectivity of 88.5%, 2,6-xylenol selectivity of 11.2% and ortho-selectivity of 99.7%, while the catalytic performance of the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 at WHSV 1.6 h−1 (2 times than that of α-Fe2O3) is phenol conversion 67.3%, o-cresol selectivity 90.1%, 2,6-xylenol selectivity 9.7% and ortho-selectivity up to 99.8%. Clearly, the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst can work at high WHSV of 1.6 h−1 nearly two times that of α-Fe2O3 while maintaining a higher reaction activity and ortho-selectivity. For the α-Fe2O3 based catalytic system, with the increase of WHSV, due to the finite contact time between the catalyst and the substrate per unit mass, the phenol conversion and the secondary methylation of o-cresol are reduced [10,38,49], so the o-cresol selectivity increase and the 2,6-xylenol selectivity decrease consistently. As showed in Fig. 1 (c), with the rise of reaction temperature, the selectivity of phenol conversion and 2,6-xylenol is gradually improved, and o-cresol selectivity is reduced. This is because the rise of reaction temperature promotes the conversion of phenol to o-cresol, and the formation of o-cresol secondarily alkylates to 2,6-xylenol [10,38,49]. When the reaction temperature over 350 °C, the phenol conversion approach to 100%, at this moment, the 2,6-xylenol selectivity gradually rises to 90%, and ortho-selectivity is reduced. This is because the rise of reaction temperature leads to the formation of other by-products (m-cresol, trimethylphenol), the coking and deactivation of catalysts. 3.3 Stability evaluation of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x As showed in Fig. 2 (a), at WHSV 1.6 h−1, (two times that of α-Fe2O3), (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 can stably and continuously react at the temperature of 350–380 °C for 2500 h without obvious deactivation. The average catalytic activity is the phenol conversion of 65.3%, o-cresol selectivity of 90.1%, 2,6-xylenol selectivity of 19.3% and ortho-selectivity of 99.4%. Fig. 2 (b) shows a comparison of performances between (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 and α-Fe2O3 during the process of 2500 h reaction. Within the first stage of 2000 h, while maintaining the catalytic activity, both catalysts rise temperatures slowly, and the heating rates are both smaller than 1.5 × 10−2 °C/h, the average heating rate of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 (350–380 °C) is smaller than α-Fe2O3 (350–420 °C). When the reaction time over 2000 h, the heating rates of the two catalysts should be both largely improved, so as to preserve the high catalytic activity. Specifically, the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 can be heated more slowly than α-Fe2O3, of which the heating rate is very rapid. By comparing the programmed temperature rise of each catalyst, we find that during the catalytic reaction at high WHSV (0.8 vs. 1.6 h−1) and long time (2000 vs. 2500 h), the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 is more active and stable than α-Fe2O3 catalyst. 3.4 Inactivation and regeneration of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x With the extension of reaction time (0–2500 h), the carbon deposit content of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 gradually increase (3.5∼10.5%), leading to the decline of SBET, Vtotal, catalytic activity and 2,6-xylenol selectivity. Meanwhile leading to the increase of o-cresol selectivity as high as 99% in Table 2 . Furthermore, 3 contact methods of N2, air (O2), and H2 different atmospheres were, respectively investigated for the catalyst regeneration. After the 2500 h reaction, the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 in N2 atmosphere at 450 °C for 4 h regeneration do not remove the carbon deposit, and the SBET, Vtotal, and catalytic activity are not significantly changed. Together with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) images in Fig. 4 (a), carbon deposits of the catalysts exist in the form of C elementary and C compounds [46], which can be hardly removed from the high-temperature N2 atmosphere. After contacting the air atmosphere at 450 °C for 4 h, the carbon deposits on the catalyst are basically all removed, and the SBET, Vtotal and activity all return to the levels of the fresh catalyst. When the catalyst run in the air (O2) atmosphere, which is placed into a fixed-bed device for 20 min of reduction in pure H2 atmosphere, the SBET, Vtotal and carbon deposits are not significantly changed, but the catalytic activity largely reduce. This is because a large part of Fe3+ reduced to Fe2+ [47], indicating that the decrease of Fe3+ active central concentration largely inactivates the performance of the Fe2O3 catalyst. The inactive (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 after 2500 h spent, which has been treated by carbon deposit removal, active center reduction and regeneration, basically return to the level of the fresh catalyst, indicating the modified catalyst is more easily regenerative, and the activity after regeneration is not significantly different compare with the fresh catalyst. 3.5 Material structure of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x Fig. 3 (a) shows that the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 has the typical α-Fe2O3 phase and hematite structure, and its diffraction peaks occurring at 24.1o, 33.2o, 35.7o, 40.9o, 49.5o and 53.9° correspond to crystal planes (012), (104), (110), (113), (024) and (116), respectively, indicating the tiny amounts of V2O5 doping do not alter the hematite structure [48]. However, the diffraction peaks of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 are obviously weaker than that of α-Fe2O3, and the full width at half maximum (FWHM) is also wider [49,50]. This is due to the V oxide addition reduces the crystallinity of α-Fe2O3, which leads to the formation of smaller crystal grains, larger SBET and more active centers. Due to the stable hematite structure, (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 maintains the advantages of low-temperature activity, ortho-selectivity and stability during the process of phenol methylation, meanwhile new catalyst generates more active centers owed to the V2O5 modification. Moreover, the reaction after 2500 h spent, the diffraction peaks of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 at 30.1o, 35.5o, 43.1o, 53.4o, 57.0o and 62.6° correspond to crystal planes (220), (311), (400), (422), (511) and (440) [49], respectively, which indicates the nature of Fe3O4 with magnetite crystal structure. After long-time catalytic reaction, a part of Fe3+ is reduced to Fe2+, but spent (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst has a stable FeO-Fe2O3 spinel structure [51,52], which is stable and efficient during the high-WHSV (over 1.5 h−1) catalytic reaction. Due to the very low concentration, V2O5 cannot find in the X-ray diffraction (XRD) a wide spectrum of the catalyst. Fig. 3 (b) shows in the Raman spectra of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 and α-Fe2O3. The (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 shows characteristic peaks at 127 and 706 cm−1 (V2O5), 220, 288, 407 and 607 cm−1 (vibration modes of A1g, Eg, Eg and Eg of Fe2O3, respectively) [53,54]. Due to the doping with V2O5, the Raman spectrum of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 also shows a blue shift. Together with XRD patterns, it indicates that the catalyst doping with V2O5 leads to a reduced trend of α-Fe2O3 crystallinity and particle size. Raman spectra shows V2O5 crystals, or new activity centers, are formed in the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005. 3.6 Valence analysis of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x Fig. 4 (a) shows the XPS full-spectra of fresh (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005, 2500 h spent (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005, and α-Fe2O3. Clearly, Fe and O are found in all three full-spectra, and corresponded to peaks of Fe 2s, Fe 3s, Fe 2p, Fe 3p, Fe LM, O KLL and O 1 s [47]. For the fresh catalyst, since the peaks of V 2p and O 1 s are very close, the V 2p peak is not found on the full-spectrum, but its binding energy at 520 eV is higher than α-Fe2O3. It indicates that the peak is possibly originated from the overlap of O 1 s and V 2p peaks, so in the following spectra, the peaks of O and V should be separated. As for the 2500 h spent catalyst, the C 1 s peak at binding energy of 285.0 eV belong to the peaks of C element and its compounds [45], indicating lots of carbon deposits are formed the reaction after spent 2500 h. As showed in Fig. 4 (b), the fresh (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005, 2500 h spent (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005, and fresh α-Fe2O3 catalysts all display the typical Fe 2p peak. In particular, the fresh catalyst shows a Fe 2p3/2 peak (a main peak at 710.48 eV and a satellite peak at 718.48 eV), which is ascribed to the Fe3+ of α-Fe2O3 [55]. By further dividing the Fe 2p3/2 peak, we find the binding energy of Fe3+ in Fe2O3 is 710.4 eV [47], and together with the reported Fe2+ of FeO at 709.8 eV [47], we estimate the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio is 98%: 2%. It is indicated the fresh catalyst is mainly composed of Fe3+, and its Fe 2p1/2 peak consist of a main peak at 723.88 eV and a satellite peak at 732.58 eV; the main peak of Fe 2p1/2 is 13.4 eV larger than that of Fe 2p3/2, which is one characteristic of the Fe 2p peak. As for the 2500 h spent catalyst, Fe 2p3/2 and Fe 2p1/2 peaks are located at 709.39 eV and 722.88 eV, respectively, with a difference of 13.4 eV, which is a typical Fe 2p peak. Moreover, no satellite peak is found. By further dividing the Fe 2p3/2 peak, we find the Fe3+/Fe2+ ratio is 45: 55%, indicating in the 2500 h spent (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst, a majority of Fe3+ is reduced to Fe2+ and the alteration of valence states may be one cause for the reduction of catalytic activity. As showed in Fig. 4 (c), binding energy of V 2p3/2 in the V 2p peak of fresh (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 is 516.91 eV, which belong to the V5+ of V2O5 [56]. As showed in Fig. 4 (d), the binding energy of O 1 s in the O 1 s peak of the fresh catalyst is 530.5 eV, which belong to the O2− of V2O5 (531.1 eV) [51] and the O2− of α-Fe2O3 (529.6 eV) [55]. 3.7 Microstructure of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x The average particle sizes of the fresh (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 are 10–20 nm in Fig. 5 (a), and the transmission electron microscopy (TEM) photos show the particles do not become agglomeration [57]. The space between crystal planes of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 is 0.224 nm in Fig. 5 (b), indicating the addition of V2O5 do not alter the crystal plane structures, but stably and uniformly bond with or replace by α-Fe2O3. As showed in Fig. 5 (c), the optimal calcination temperature of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 is 450 °C, and when the calcination temperature at 650 °C, the average particle sizes of the catalyst are 50–60 nm. Moreover, partial aggregation is clearly showed, and together with Fig. 1 (a), it indicates the higher calcination temperature (e.g. 650 °C) lead to form aggregation and pore collapse of catalyst [57]. The average particle sizes of the fresh catalyst about 10–20 nm, and no catalyst aggregation is found in Fig. 5 (a) and (b). After the 1500 h reaction, however the average particle sizes of the 1500 h spent (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst is 40–50 nm, and aggregation and carbon deposits of catalyst is significantly increased. After the 2500 h reaction, the average particle sizes of 50–80 nm, and aggregation and carbon deposits become more and more obvious [57], which leading to the large reduction of catalytic activity. 3.7 Acid-base property of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x As showed in Fig. 6 (a), the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 possesses more acid centers, especially strong acid centers, while α-Fe2O3 has more weak acid centers. Thus, the doping of V2O5 endows the catalyst with more active centers. Together with the catalytic performance assessment mentioned above in Table 1 , we think that one reason for the improved catalytic activity is the high concentrations of moderately strong acid centers (300–500 °C). The (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst after 1000 h spent contains fewer acid centers, especially moderately strong acid centers. The possible reason is that during the long-time reaction, the occupancy of active centers, carbon deposits, and the alteration of catalyst structures leads to a reduction in the number of active centers. As showed in Fig. 6 (b), compared with α-Fe2O3, the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 possesses more base centers (mainly weak base centers). Though the changes of base centers are not as significant as those of acid centers, certain amounts of moderately strong base centers are formed. Together with the catalytic activity assessment mentioned above, we think these base centers also cooperate with the acid centers and synergistically contribute to the improvement of catalytic activity. After the 2500 h reaction, the spent (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 contains fewer base centers and fewer moderately strong base centers compared with the fresh catalyst. As shown in the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst after spent 2500 h, the carbon deposits, aggregation and alteration of acid/base centers lead to a reduction in the numbers of acid and base centers, and a decline in the catalytic activity [43,44]. As showed in Fig. 6 (c) and (d), With the increase of reaction time, the acid centers of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst decreased gradually, especially the amount of medium-strong acid centers. At the same time, the base centers of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst decreased gradually, especially the amount of weak base centers, the catalytic performance of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 decreased due to the decrease of its acid-base centers. The obvious reduction of acid and base centers due to carbon deposits, aggregation and coking after the continuous 2500 h reaction, which is the multiple cause for the catalytic deactivation. The pyridine infrared spectra in Fig. 6 (e) shows that (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 and α-Fe2O3 both have L-acid centers and B-acid centers. In particular, the peaks at 1448, 1540 and 1491 cm−1 are ascribed to the L-acid, B-acid, and L+B acid of α-Fe2O3, respectively; the peaks at 1451, 1545 and 1493 cm−1 are attributed to the L-acid, B-acid, and L+B acids of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005, respectively. The concentrations of L-acid and B-acid in (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 increase and the positions shift compared with α-Fe2O3, indicating new L-acid centers (V5+) and new B-acid centers (V-OH-Fe) are formed in (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005. These new active centers can improve the acid/base properties and catalytic performances of α-Fe2O3, which further confirms the mechanism of acid and base synergistic catalysis during the phenol methylation with methanol over (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts. 3.8 Oxygen vacancy of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x The UV-Vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy was used to investigate the composition of the vanadium species in the samples. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), both the original α-Fe2O3 and (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalysts exhibit dominant absorption, corresponding to Fe2O3 nanoparticles [58]. The absorption enhances in (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst, consistent with the incorporation of some crystallographic V5+ in the Fe2O3 framework. The incorporation of V5+ into the Fe2O3 framework will be confirmed by XPS, Raman and HRTEM photos presented above. In order to prove the generation of oxygen vacancy in the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalyst, electron spin resonance spectroscopy (ESR) was used to detect the possible unpaired electrons (oxygen defects) in the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalyst. As shown in Fig. 7 (b), α-Fe2O3 has obviously less ESR peak, indicating that the α-Fe2O3 contains less oxygen vacancy, while (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 catalyst at g = 2.001 shows an obvious symmetric ESR signal, indicating that electrons are trapped in the oxygen vacancy [59]. This also proves that oxygen vacancy can be obtained using the modification of V element, which is consistent with the other characterization results. The role of oxygen vacancy is that, the more oxygen vacancy generates in the catalyst, the more oxygen atoms in the per unit mass of catalyst will increase, and the amount of oxygen atoms in Fe2O3 will increase after the V modification. From the perspective of catalytic mechanism, oxygen atoms are used to adsorb and activate methanol, thus increasing the phenol conversion and the catalyst activity after the V modification. 3.9 Acid-base actives and mechanism As shown in Fig. 8 (a), it indicates that as an alkaline poisoning reagent, pyridine occupies the acid center of the catalyst, with increasing pyridine concentration and reaction time, the catalyst activity gradually decreases because more and more pyridine adsorbed on the acid center of the catalyst greatly occupies the acid center of catalyst. It suggests that the acid center (V, Fe, V-OH-Fe) may be the active center of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8 (b), this indicates that as an acid substance, acetic acid destroys or occupies the base center (O2−) of the catalyst. With increasing acetic acid concentration and reaction time, the catalyst activity gradually decreases because the base center of the catalyst is occupied or destroyed by acetic acid. However, a small amount of acetic acid can promote the activity of the catalyst. The amount of acetic acid increases with the reactive process, leading to the significant impact on the activity of the catalyst. It indicates that the base center of the catalyst is also the active center of the catalyst. As shown in Fig. 8 (c), for the industrial gas-phase alkylation of phenol reacts with methanol in the presence of α-Fe2O3 catalyst at 320 ∼350 °C, ratio of 1.0:2.0 ∼ 5.0:0.5 and space velocity of 0.2 ∼ 1.6 h−1. Regardless of the change of phenol conversions, the ortho-position selectivity of phenol always remaining above 99% (sum of o-cresol and 2,6-dimethylphenol). Through related experiments, in the Scheme 2 , it is concluded that phenol is adsorbed on L-acid center in the form of phenoxyl anions, and its H proton is separated from phenol and adsorbed on the base center of catalyst (O2−), the H proton adsorbed on the base center activates methanol, the resulting methyl cations, which is at the transition state and adsorption state of the reaction, form o-cresol and 2,6-dimethylphenol by synergism. The mechanism of phenol alkylation with methanol over α-Fe2O3 catalyst is similar to that on the metal oxide catalyst (MgO, TiO2) reported in the previous literature, thus the similar mechanisms prove each other and are the results of the reactions by the synergistic effect of the acid center and base center [10,49]. Through the modification of V element, more oxygen vacancies were formed in the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalyst, which increased the BET surface area and formed more acid-base active centers, so that the performance of the catalyst was improved. 4 Conclusions The (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 is found to show the optimal catalytic performance based on our characterization, and the catalyst structures and associated structure-activity relationships were explored. At suitable reaction conditions, the (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 could stably work at higher space velocity (1.6 vs. 0.8 h−1). The modified catalyst reserved the structure of α-Fe2O3, as V in the form of V2O5 bonded with α-Fe2O3. Compared with pure α-Fe2O3, the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts possessed more moderately strong acid centers, more base centers, and more oxygen vacancies. These acid-base centers contributed to the improvement of catalytic activity. The stability of (α-Fe2O3)0.995(V2O5)0.005 during 2500 h of reaction was investigated and its characteristics were further investigated, aiming to explain the causes for catalytic deactivation. Under the process condition the catalyst deactivation after reaction was mainly caused by carbon deposits, catalyst aggregation, pore collapse, and alteration of active center valence states. The initial catalytic activity was recovered after regeneration. The catalysts could be repeatedly prepared without significant loss of catalytic performance. The high repeatability and mature process accord with the high standards for preparation of efficient industrial catalysts. coredata.dc:description: A series of highly active and ortho-position selective catalysts based on (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts were proposed for the C-methylation of phenol with methanol. The (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts were synthesized by coprecipitation method of Fe and V elements and microwave drying. The chemical composition, material structure, acid-base properties, and structure-activity relationship of (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts were systematically analyzed by the techniques of XRD, XPS, TEM, N2 adsorption-desorption, Raman, UV-Vis, ESR, NH3/CO2-TPD and Pyridine-IR. The (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts have the double advantages of high activity and high stability for the methylation of phenol due to the high BET surface area, large total pore volume, dispersive active sites and enhanced acid-base property. o-cresol and 2,6-xylenol were the main products, and nearly 100% selectivity to the ortho-position of phenol and 90% selectivity to o-cresol were obtained. Furthermore, the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts possess long lifetime over 2500 h and high activity at a weight hourly space velocity of 1.6 h−1 compared with the microwave-dried α-Fe2O3 catalyst. The doping of vanadium improves the activity and stability of α-Fe2O3 catalyst, which attributes to the modification of catalyst structure, especially the improvement of acid-base centers and oxygen vacancy. Recently the (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts have been stably and efficiently applied in industry for the methylation of phenol.
coredata.dc:title: (α-Fe2O3)1- x (V2O5) x catalysts with enhanced acid-base property for the highly active and ortho-selective methylation of phenol
